image.altText: Grant Stevens in uniform next to bare trees outside a building

props.synopsis: South Australia's Police Commissioner says he will speak with Major Crime detectives before deciding if he will seek a review of the decision to grant Snowtown murderer James Vlassakis parole.

title.children: Snowtown murderer's parole being considered by police and victims' commissioners

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas holding a piece of metal.

props.synopsis: Australian smelters are competing with Chinese companies that are "bigger, faster, better and cheaper". So, is the federal government right to keep the local industry afloat?

title.children: Risky bailout or smart geopolitics? The $135m smelter rescue divides opinion

image.altText: cars splash water over the road as pedestrians try cross flooded roads and footpaths

props.synopsis: A wet finish to the year is increasingly favoured across Australia as a major climate driver emerges for the first time in three years.

title.children: Major climate driver signals wet August to December

image.altText: Inside the historical Mortlock Wing of the State Library of South Australia.

props.synopsis: Adelaide's premier library has been recognised by the 1000 Libraries Awards as second most beautiful in the world, while Victoria has snagged seventh spot.

title.children: The Australian libraries among top 10 most beautiful in the world

image.altText: Travis Boak celebrates by punching his right fist in the air and yelling with delight to the crowd

props.synopsis: Port Adelaide great, and three-time All-Australian, Travis Boak has announced his retirement from the AFL

title.children: Port Adelaide great Travis Boak announces retirement from AFL

image.altText: Police tape at the front of a brick hosue

props.synopsis: Johnathon Malcolm Goodfellow, who killed a father by stabbing him in the chest in Adelaide's northern suburbs two years ago, has been sentenced to at least eight years behind bars.

title.children: Man jailed for fatal stabbing amid motorcycle dispute

image.altText: Adelaide Oval with the River Torrens and the pedestrian bridge with green signage on it

props.synopsis: Adelaide's River Torrens has battled pollution and an image problem over the decades — but there is now a proposal to bring back swimming to the waterway.

title.children: The River Torrens has battled pollution — can it be safe for swimming?

image.altText: An aerial photo of Thurloo Downs National Parks following it's purchase by national parks.

props.synopsis: Visitors will be able to access a vast array of wetlands, woodland and waterholes across the 430,000-hectare site in far west NSW, which is home to dozens of threatened species.

title.children: Former outback sheep station set to open as national park next year

image.altText: Two dads do primary school pick-up of their kids in Brisbane

props.synopsis: Productivity is an economic concept, but it should be fired by the universal human experience of being driven mad by unnecessary stuff that makes life harder.

title.children: Productivity starts in our kitchens and at the school gate

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers in suit and red tie at a press conference with flag in background.

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says AI will be a "game changer for our economy", arguing it has the potential to support Australia's "economic goals" and lift living standards. Follow live.

title.children: Chalmers 'optimistic' AI can be 'force for good'

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Despite AUKUS and tariff doubts, State Department says US-Australia relations 'terrific'
Marles says government 'listening' to Australians on Gaza
Albanese talks Gaza and makes plans to meet with Macron at UN General Assembly

image.altText: A composite image with two pictures of a left hand with stitches from the index finger down to the wrist.

props.synopsis: A man who almost lost his hand in a machete attack at a Melbourne shopping centre has called into question security measures and is pleading for the government to act.

title.children: 'Not safe anywhere': Machete attacks instil fears in victims and witnesses

image.altText: Sami looks out over his front porch at his home, with a pensive expression.

props.synopsis: Sami Muamar says the grief, anguish and mental toll of constant death have forced him to leave the job he loves.

title.children: Overwhelming grief of Gaza deaths forces principal from job he loves

image.altText: Child holds up colored sign that reads "we value our teachers"

props.synopsis: Today's strike action is expected to affect more than half a million students at about 1,200 state schools.

title.children: Queensland teachers striking over 'pretty dire situation'

image.altText: Rare earth samples

props.synopsis: We rank amongst the world's richest nations when it comes to personal wealth but, in terms of our economy and particularly its complexity, we sit amongst the world's poorest — and the situation is progressively getting worse.

title.children: Australia in race to wind back industrial devolution

image.altText: Oskar Speck in his kayak

props.synopsis: Unemployed and seeking a better life, Oscar Speck pushed his kayak into the water of the Danube River and began paddling downriver. He didn't stop until he reached Australia.

title.children: After paddling 50,000km, Australian police arrested this German kayaker

image.altText: A middle aged man in a car waves and smiles

props.synopsis: Tasmania's governor reappoints Jeremy Rockliff as premier but says it will be parliament that ultimately decides whether his Liberal minority government survives.

title.children: #Breaking: Rockliff reappointed as premier after meeting with Tasmanian governor

image.altText: A Centrelink/Medicare sign outside a branch.

props.synopsis: Almost a thousand jobseekers had their income support payments unlawfully terminated over two years, the federal watchdog has found, cautioning the breach likely had a "profound if not catastrophic" impact on vulnerable people.

title.children: 'Should have learned from Robodebt': Welfare payments unlawfully cut off

image.altText: A Japanese man wearing a dark suit and blue 'Nuke Free' cap, smiling while standing next to a waterway

props.synopsis: Thousands of people are set to gather to commemorate the 80th anniversary and the catastrophic impacts of the nuclear bombing of Japan's Hiroshima during World War II, including survivors who are calling for the world to be free of atomic weapons.

title.children: Eight decades after the Hiroshima nuclear bombing, survivors have one demand

image.altText: A house in a large green field.

props.synopsis: Building a house on the wrong block of land does not happen very often, but it happens enough that some states and countries have laws in place to deal with it.

title.children: What the law says about building a house on the wrong block

image.altText: Close up image of musician ozzy osbourne while he is wearing blue circular sunglasses

props.synopsis: The death certificate was submitted by Osbourne's daughter, Aimée Osbourne, the New York Times reported.

title.children: Ozzy Osbourne died of a heart attack, death certificate shows

image.altText: A group of people on the beach helping overturn a capsized speedboat

props.synopsis: A speedboat travelling from Nusa Penida to Bali has capsized after being struck by large waves, killing two people and leaving one missing.

title.children: Five Australians among 80 on boat that capsized in Bali

image.altText: Two ibis on a fence.

props.synopsis: As we count down to discovering Australia's most underrated animal, there are plenty of worthy contenders that didn't make it into this year's top 10.

title.children: Australia has a love-hate relationship with the ibis, but the bird's not underrated

image.altText: A man wearing a checked shirt with gray hair

props.synopsis: Australian musician Col Joye, the first Australian pop performer to reach number one on the local charts, has died at the age of 89.

title.children: Australian musician Col Joye dies aged 89, remembered as 'true gentleman'

image.altText: A man carries a victim, their feet are seen as they carry them out.

props.synopsis: Surging floodwaters and a torrent of mud have swept through a village in the northern Indian Himalayan state of Uttarakhand.

title.children: Village washed away and several missing after flash floods in India

image.altText: Bill and Hillary Clinton walking through a procession at Donald Trump's second inauguration.

props.synopsis: Politicians on the House Oversight Committee also request the Justice Department provide them with files and depositions from its investigation into the deceased financier.

title.children: Clintons among figures subpoenaed in US congressional Epstein probe

image.altText: A woman with long blonde hair smiles while looking to her right.

props.synopsis: As the WA Coroner hands down her findings into the murder of Lynn Cannon, it is up to the government and community to work together to bring an end to domestic violence.

title.children: Murders like Lynn’s are predictable and preventable, so why aren't they being stopped?

image.altText: A National Capital Authority blue sign on a building site marking the planned future location for a Russian Embassy.

props.synopsis: Australia passed a law in 2023 cancelling Russia's lease for a planned embassy near Parliament House, but Russia is now disputing that in the High Court.

title.children: Russia takes Australia to High Court over cancelled lease

image.altText: A wind turbine under construction at a remote mine site.

props.synopsis: As many of its delegates pour significant investment into renewables systems, the keynote panel at this year's Diggers and Dealers conference suggests Australia's switch to a fully renewable grid is dead in the water.

title.children: Mining forum panel questions Australia's 'zombie' energy transition

image.altText: A rocky granite island in the ocean.

props.synopsis: When Tasmania broke away from New South Wales politically in the 19th century it was decided all islands south of Wilsons Promontory would belong to the new colony, but it didn't quite work out that way.

title.children: Charting bungle created 'land border' between Tasmania and Victoria

image.altText: Man in suit (Macron) stands as a flem appears in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A man who stopped to light a cigarette from the fire at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier under the Arc de Triomphe in France has been arrested.

title.children: France arrests man who lit cigarette from war memorial flame

image.altText: Colourful sketched map with Latin writing at the top and many intersecting lines across the page.

props.synopsis: Cartographers in the 1600s had bold ideas of Australia, and some incredible methods of depicting those ideas in maps and globes.

title.children: 17th-century mapmakers had vivid ideas about Australia. They were wrong

image.altText: An underwater photo shows coral of varying colours, with fish swimming in between

props.synopsis: The Australian Institute of Marine Science says coral cover in the Great Barrier Reef has declined after mass bleaching events, with experts warning it faces a future of "increased volatility".

title.children: Great Barrier Reef coral cover decline shows 'ecosystem under stress'

image.altText: Nibok refugee settlement on Nauru. It is a row of rectangular accommodation units.

props.synopsis: Australia is seeking to deport three people released under the NZYQ decision to the tiny Pacific nation in exchange for an undisclosed payment, but their removal has been stalled since February due to court challenges.

title.children: UN urges Australian government to halt deportation of man to Nauru

image.altText: OceanGate Titan submersible floating at the surface of the ocean

props.synopsis: The US Coast Guard finds OceanGate's chief executive ignored warnings from employees and that the company 'actively retaliated' against those who spoke up.

title.children: Titan submersible's firm had 'reckless disregard for safety', report finds
